Description: Primary key of the study.
Researcher ID of the first screener.
Researcher ID of the second screener (in case of double checking).
General notes on the study that are relevant for all models within the study.
Model specific notes that are relevant only for a given model within the study.
Indicates the number of the figure from which the impulse response is taken
Indicates the page on which the impulse response (figure or table) is displayed.
Indicates if there is a graphical representation of the irfs in the study.
Indicates if the impulse response function represents cumulated effects.
Type of short term interest rate variable which is shocked.
Shock size in basis points or percent.
Note if the axis scale needs to be transformed to be a percentage scale.
Dependent (outcome) variable codes.
Level of the confidence bounds or standard errors.
The outcome variable representing the main research interest of the study.
Indicates if the effect estimate based on the model specification is preferred in the study.
Indicates if an instrumental variable approch is used for identification.
Indicates whether a forecast-based strategy is used for shock identification.
Indicates if a narrative strategy based on narrative records or sentiments of central bank statements is used for shock identification.
Indicates if an event study or a similar direct measurement of the monetary policy shock is used for shock identification.
Indicates if a recursive ("Cholesky") ordering is used for shock identification.
Indicates if a non-recursive structural VAR approach is used for shock identification (no Cholesky).
Indicates if a sign restriction approach is used for shock identification.
Indicates if a high frequency approach is used for shock identification.
Indicates if a heteroskedasticity-based approach is used for shock identification.
Indicates if shock identification is based on long-run restrictions.
Indicates if the identification strategy does not correspond to one of the other variables in identification_strategy.
Indicates if a vector autoregression model (VAR) is used for estimation.
Indicates if a local projections method is used for estimation.
Indicates if a vector error correction model is used for estimation.
Indicates if a dynamic ols model, such as an autoregressive distributed lag model, is used for estimation.
Indicates if a factor-augmented VAR model is used for estimation.
Indicates if a time-varying parameter VAR models is used for estimation.
Indicates if a global VAR model (no panel) is used for estimation.
Indicates if a Bayesian approach is used for estimation.
Indicates if a dynamic stochastic general equilibrium (DSGE) model is used for estimation.
Indicates if an other VAR approach is used for estimation.
Indicates that the effect is estimated for a 'downswing' or 'recession' regime.
Indicates that the effect is estimated for an 'upswing' or 'boom' regime.
Indicates that the effect is estimated for a supply-constrained regime.
Indicates that the effect is estimated for a demand-constrained regime.
Indicates that the effect is estimated for an interest rate hike only.
Indicates that the effect is estimated for an interest rate cut only.
Annual data is used for effect estimation.
Quarterly data is used for effect estimation.
Monthly data is used for effect estimation.
ISO 2 codes of the countries for which the effect is estimated.
Number of countries used in the estimation sample of the model.
Indicates if a panel data method (e.g. panel VAR) is used for estimation.
Start date of the sample that is used for estimation.
End date of the sample that is used for estimation.
Sample size for estimation.
Indicates that a commodity price variable is included as a control variable.
Indicates that a measure for the output gap is included as a control variable.
Indicates that a variable for financial development is included as a control variable.
Indicates that a measure of economic globalisation is included as a control variable.
Indicates that central bank independence is included as a control variable.
Indicates that the exchange rate regime is included as a control variable.
Indicates that inflation expectations are included as a control variable.
Indicates that a foreign interest rate is included as a control variable.
Indicates that a exchange rate is included as a control variable.
Indicates that a long-run interest rate is included as a control variable.
Indicates that the monetary policy shock is explicitly defined in terms of the interest rate.
Indicates that the monetary policy shock is explicitly defined in terms of a conventional monetary policy shock.
Indicates that the monetary policy shocks have been decomposed into different components.
Indicates the exchange rate regime of the country for which the model is estimated.
Average inflation rate over the sample period for which the output coefficient was estimated
Inflation variability, standard deviation inflation over time
Average trade openness over the sample period (KOF index)
Average financial openness over the sample period
Average GDP per capita over the sample period
Average financial development over the sample period (domestic credit to private sector in % of GDP)
Average central bank independence over the sample period (index)
Average unemployment rate over the sample period
Share of years which are supply constrained, or with supply price shocks
Number of citations (Ehrenbergerova et al. 2022 use google scholar citations within the first three years p.17)
Journal impact factor
Indicates that there is an institutional affiliation of one of the authors and/or the publication format with central banks.
Reason for exclusion after full text screening for definition see: https://github.com/META-CMP/data/issues/37
